understanding.eli5:
To understand this better, let's look at the problem in reverse and find the chance that two people do not share the same birthday. Imagine a world where the year is only 10 days long with no months. We have two people in this 10-day year, and we want to know the probability that they don't share a birthday.

If one is born on a specific day, how many options does the other person have to avoid sharing that birthday? Nine, right? So, the chance of not sharing a birthday is 9/10, or 0.9, which equals 90%.

Now, let's add a third person. What are the odds that this third person doesn't share a birthday with the first two? If the first two have already taken two days, the third can be born on any of the 8 remaining days. So, the probability of not sharing a birthday is 8/10, or 0.8, or 80%. Subtracting gives a 20% chance of sharing. Using the Multiplication Rules of Probability, we find the probability of three people not sharing a birthday in a 10-day year: (10/10) x (9/10) x (8/10) = 0.72 = 72%.

Now, let’s do the same with a 365-day year and 23 people. The probability of not sharing birthdays is (365/365) x (364/365) x (363/365) x (362/365) ... = 0.4927 = 49.27%, meaning that 50.73% of them do share a birthday.

This video clarified it well for me.

index.title: The birthday 'paradox'
index.subjectDescription: Known as a paradox because it’s counterintuitive, the birthday problem shows that with only 23 people, there is over a 50% chance that two share the same birthday.
index.siteInstructions: On the 'Check it out' page, you can test this using data from Spanish FIFA football teams (sourced from here).

theMain.noResults: Apparently, there are no two players on this team who share a birthday. That's how probability works.

first.title: The question
first.content: In a group, how many people do you think it takes for two to share a birthday?

second.content: With 23 people, there’s a 50% chance that two of them share a birthday.

third.content: With 40 people, there’s an 89.1% chance. So, next time you’re at a family dinner with 40 people, think about their birthdays—you might find a match.

fourth.content: With 60 people, there’s a 99.4% chance that two of them share a birthday.

fifth.title: The math behind this is simple
fifth.content: You can understand it further here. (365/365) x (364/365) x (363/365) x (362/365)... = 0.4927 = 49.27% probability of no shared birthdays, meaning a 50.73% chance that they do.
